si0014.svg svg 2127 ALTIMG APCATA 120524 120524 S0926-860X(25)00425-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120524 The Authors Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the approach adopted in the work. (1) Several bifunctional catalysts were synthetized by varying the procedure. In all cases the Pd precursor was Pd(OAc)2, and both the Pd and the sulphate precursors were added through mechanochemistry. (2) The synthetized catalysts were tested in the one pot conversion of furfural (or furfuryl alcohol) to isopropyl levulinate using isopropanol both as solvent and hydrogen donor. (3) All of them were subjected to a detailed investigation through a multi-technique approach, in order to understand the phenomena occurring at the different stages of the synthesis. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Comparative analysis of the catalysts performance in furfural (FF) conversion to isopropyl levulinate (IPLEV) (a) and furfuryl alcohol (FA) conversion to IPLEV (b) obtaining IPFE as intermediate/by-product in both cases. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K of the ZrO2/C composite, S0 and S1-X catalysts (a), and of catalysts containing the same 5 wt% sulphate loading but synthetized through different methods (b). Both adsorption (full curves) and desorption (dotted lines) isotherms are reported. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of the ZrO2/C composite, S0 and S0–5 (a); the S1-X catalysts (b); and catalysts containing the same 5 wt% sulphate loading but synthetized through different methods (c). The main diffraction peaks ascribed to t-ZrO2 (♦) -JCPDS card NO. 371484-, m-ZrO2 (★) -JCPDS card NO. 42–1164- and metallic Pd (●) -JCPDS card NO. 65–2867- are also labelled. The patterns are vertically stacked for clarity. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR results in Pd region (0 ºC to 70 ºC) and in SO4 region (100 ºC to 600 ºC), S0 and S0–5 (a); the S1-X catalysts (b); and catalysts containing the same 5 wt% sulphate loading but synthetized through different methods (c). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 IR spectra of CO adsorbed at room temperature on S0 and S1-X (X = 3, 5, 10, 20 %) catalysts (a) and Pd-based catalysts obtained from different synthesis with the same nominal amount of sulphate groups (b). The spectra are reported in the ʋ(CO) region after subtraction of that collected prior to dosage, and normalized to the thickness of the pellets for quantitative comparison. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 IR spectra of CO adsorbed at liquid nitrogen temperature on S0 (a), S1–5 (b), S1–20 (c), S2–5 (d), S3–5 (e) and S4–5 (f). The spectrum collected at the maximum CO coverage is shown in bold, while the others are collected upon gradual degassing at liquid nitrogen temperature. The shift of the ʋ(CO) band ascribed to Brønsted acid sites with respect to CO in the gas phase is also reported. The insets show the evolution of the same spectra in the ʋ(OH) region. Fig. 7 Table 1 Catalytic performance of furfural conversion to alkyl levulinates over different catalysts. Table 2 Catalyst SSA (m 2 /g) VTOT (cm 3 /g) VMESO (cm 3 /g) t-ZrO 2 (%) ZrO 2 /C 296 0.4 0.26 64 S0 282 0.31 0.18 20 S1–5 43 0.15 0.07 21 S1–10 41 0.19 0.08 26 S2–5 38 0.17 0.06 29 S3–5 309 0.29 0.16 18 S4–5 69 0.21 0.10 38 Table 3 Summary of the H2-TPR data obtained for the investigated catalysts. For each catalyst, the nominal Pd2+ and SO 4 2 − loadings are also reported. The H2-TPR curves are divided in two main regions, corresponding to Pd2+→Pd0 reduction and SO 4 2 − → SO 2 reduction, respectively. For each region, Tmax (i.e. the maximum temperature values of the hydrogen consumption peak), the measured H2 consumption (mmol/g) and the H2/Pd2+ or H2/ SO 4 2 − ratio are reported (n.a. = not applicable). Understanding why multifunctional catalysts fail is critical to advancing biomass valorisation strategies. In this study, we systematically investigate the dynamic deactivation mechanisms that limit the one-pot cascade conversion of furfural (FF) to alkyl levulinates via sequential hydrogenation and alcoholysis. To this end, we designed a series of bifunctional Pd/SO4 2 --ZrO2–carbon composites derived from NH2-UiO-66(Zr) through pyrolysis, followed by mechanochemical functionalization. Rather than focusing on catalytic performance, our goal was to elucidate how variations in synthetic protocol – specifically the sequence of pyrolysis, sulphation, calcination atmosphere, and reduction steps – influence structural evolution, Pd–sulphur interactions, and active site accessibility. Through a broad multi-technique characterization campaign, we reveal that Pd deactivation by sulphur is a gradual and reversible process, closely related to the catalyst’s thermal history. While high-temperature H₂ treatments can restore Pd accessibility, they also strip Brønsted acidity by removing surface SO42— groups, revealing a compromise between hydrogenation and alcoholysis functions. These findings highlight the complexity of designing truly cooperative multifunctional catalysts and the importance of integrated synthetic–reactive strategies that move beyond performance optimization alone. Graphical Abstract Keywords MOF-derived catalyst Biomass valorization FF hydrogenation Alkyl levulinates Pd-sulfur poison Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the last decades, biomass-derived platform molecules have gained significant attention as precursors for high-value chemicals. Among these, furfural (FF) stands out with an annual production of around 200,000 tons [1]. An attractive derivative of FF is furfuryl alcohol (FA), which constitutes about 65 % of FF production. FA is primarily used in the production of resins and as a versatile intermediate for synthesizing other valuable chemicals. One notable application of FA is in the production of alkyl levulinates, which are regarded as green solvents and fuel additives that enhance oxygen content in gasoline, promoting complete combustion and reducing harmful emissions [2]. Recent efforts have focused on the direct conversion of FF into alkyl levulinates through a sequential catalytic process involving hydrogenation of FF to FA, followed by alcoholysis of FA [2,3]. This one-pot cascade transformation is mechanistically challenging (Scheme S1, where is reflected all steps involve and the detail mechanism), requiring bifunctional catalysts capable of both hydrogenation and alcoholysis [4,5]. Progress in this field is often assessed in terms of yield and catalyst performance. In contrast, our objective is to understand why multifunctional catalysts often fail to deliver the expected results. By shifting the focus from performance to failure modes, we seek to uncover the underlying causes of catalyst deactivation, with the ultimate goal of informing more rational catalyst design. To this end, we synthetized and investigated a series of Pd-functionalized, sulphated ZrO₂–carbon composites derived from the pyrolysis of NH₂-UiO-66(Zr) metal-organic framework (MOF). This catalyst design was guided by several rationales: • Pd nanoparticle (NPs) are effective in the selective hydrogenation of FF [6–9]; • Sulphate groups provide Brønsted acidity [10,11], promoting FA alcoholysis; • ZrO2, known for its stability and Lewis acidity [12], was combined with carbon to enhance surface area and microwave responsiveness [13]; • The MOF-templated synthesis enables porosity control and homogeneous phase distribution, overcoming limitations of conventional hybrid materials [13−16]; • Mechanochemistry was used as clean, solvent-free method for post-synthetic functionalization [17–19]; • Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) using isopropanol as both solvent and H-donor was adopted as a greener alternative to molecular hydrogen [20,21]; • Microwave-assisted heating offers several advantages at the exploratory level: rapid reaction kinetics, minimal solvent usage, and improved energy efficiency [2]. However, combining Pd and SO4 2- groups within the same material is known to trigger mutual interference and activity loss [22–24]. To investigate this interplay, we adopted the approach schematically illustrated in Fig. 1. We systematically varied synthetic parameters - including the sequence of synthetic steps, the thermal treatment atmosphere, and the sulphate loading - and we explored how these factors influence catalyst structure and function. The resulting catalysts were evaluated in the one-pot conversion of FF (or FA) to isopropyl levulinate, under microwave-assisted CTH conditions. A multi-technique characterization campaign was undertaken to probe the effects of each synthetic step on active site accessibility, phase evolution, and Pd speciation - ranging from PdO to PdS and PdSO4. Although the catalysts did not achieve optimal performance, we were able to correlate structural transformations and sulphur-related poisoning with specific deactivation patterns. These insights provide a framework for understanding the inherent limitations of multifunctional systems and pave the way for more resilient catalytic designs. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials 2-aminoterephthalic acid (> 99 %, Sigma Aldrich), zirconium(IV) chloride (ZrCl4) (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), palladium(II) acetate (Pd(OAc)2) (99.98 %, Sigma-Aldrich), ammonium sulphate (>99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), methanol (MeOH) (>99.9 %, Panreac), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (>99.9 %, Panreac), furfural (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), furfuryl alcohol (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and 2-propanol (>99.9 %, Panreac) were used as purchased without any further purification. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of NH2-UiO-66(Zr) NH2-UiO-66(Zr) was synthetized as described in ref.[25] Briefly, ZrCl4 and 2-amino terephtalic acid were added (1:1 molar ratio) and stirred under 50 mL of DMF for 30 min. The aforementioned solution was transferred to a 125 mL stainless steel-lined Teflon autoclave and heated at 120 ºC for 24 h. After filtration, the resulting precipitate was washed twice with DMF and twice with MeOH. Subsequently, the material was dried in an oven for 12 h in air atmosphere. 2.2.2 Pd-based catalyst derived from NH2-UiO-66(Zr) Several Pd-based catalysts were synthetized starting from NH2-UiO-66(Zr) and Pd(acac)2, changing the atmosphere and temperatures of the thermal treatment as illustrated in Fig. 1. Synthesis 0 (S0). NH2-UiO-66(Zr) was pyrolyzed at 800 ºC under N2 flow (50 mL/min) with a ramp of 2 ºC/min, obtaining a ZrO2/C composite. 2 g of ZrO2/C were then ball-milled with 42 mg of Pd(OAc)2 at 350 rpm for 10 min, using an interval of 10 s each 65 s of milling. This material was then heated in N2 flow (50 mL/min) up to 400 ºC (3 ºC/min) and finally maintained at this temperature for 2 h in H2 flow (10 mL/min), obtaining 1 % Pd-ZrO2/C hereafter label as S0. Synthesis 1 (S1). A defined amount of ammonium sulphate ((NH4)2SO4) was added to 2 g of catalyst S0 and ball-milled at same conditions as above. The material obtained was introduced into a muffle furnace and heated in air up to 500 ºC (3 ºC/min) and maintained at this temperature for an additional 2 h. The percentage of sulphate added to S0 was varied from 3 % to 20 %. The final catalysts were named S1-X (S1–3, S1–5, S1–10 and S1–20), where X represents the % of sulphate precursor added to S0 in weight. Notice that a fraction of S0 with 5 % of ammonium sulphate was conserved for some characterization studies before any thermal treatment and will be named as S0–5. Synthesis 2 (S2). Another catalyst was obtained following the same method as S1 with 5 % of ammonium sulphate with an additional step involving reduction at 100 ºC under a hydrogen flow (10 mL/min). This material will be designated as S2–5. Synthesis 3 (S3). This synthesis involves a treatment similar to S1 with a difference in the last step, in which instead of calcining the sample after the addition of ammonium sulphate, the material was reduced in H2 (10 mL/min) at 500 ºC with a ramp of 3 ºC/min. This catalyst will be named S3–5. Synthesis 4 (S4). A final catalyst was obtained from NH2-UiO-66(Zr) upon adding Pd(OAc)2 (to achieve 1 wt% of Pd) through ball-milling under same conditions previously described, followed by pyrolysis at 800 ºC under a nitrogen flow (50 mL/min) for 2 h, with a ramp rate of 2 ºC/min. The so obtained sample was then functionalized with ammonium sulphate via mechanochemistry under identical conditions as before, to achieve 5 % of sulphates. The material was then heated in air muffle furnace (3 ºC/min) until reaching 500 ºC and maintained at this temperature for additional 2 h. Finally, the material was reduced under an H2 flow (10 mL/min) at 100 ºC for 2 h. This catalyst is labelled as S4–5. 2.3 Catalytic conversion of furfural The catalytic performances of the synthetized catalysts were investigated in the one pot conversion of furfural or furfuryl alcohol to isopropyl levulinate. Reactions were carried out in a Microwave reactor (CEM Discover 2.0) using isopropanol both as solvent and hydrogen donor, with the following conditions: 200 ºC, furfural or furfuryl alcohol 0.2 mol/L concentration and a maximum pressure of 300 psi. The products were collected after 1 h of reaction and identified by GC-MS (Agilent 7820 A GC/5977B) equipped with a HP-5ms (30 m x 0.25 mm×0.25 μm) column. The injector and detector temperatures were set to 300ºC. Column conditions (oven) were started at 80ºC for 2 min, then increased to 130ºC in 2ºC/min (maintaining 180 ºC stable for 5 min). Product quantification was carried out using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 5890) with a flame ionization detector (FID) and non-polar fused silica ihidroxy SUPELCO EQUITY TM-1” (60 m x 0.25 mm×0.25 μm) column. The detector and injector temperature were set to 250 °C. The oven temperature was initially set to 60 °C, then ramped to 180 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, and held at this temperature for 26 min. In all cases, the carbon mass balance based on the quantified products (furfuryl alcohol, isopropyl levulinate, and minor byproducts) was above 95 %, confirming the reliability of the analytical data. 2.4 Catalysts characterization 2.4.1 Texture and structure Textural properties were determined using N2 physisorption measurements at 77 K with a Micrometrics ASAP 2000 instrument. Prior to analysis, the samples (∼0.2 g) were degassed at 130°C (P < 0.01 mbar) overnight. The textural properties were evaluated by using the software Microactive (Micromeritics). The Specific Surface Areas (SSAs) of the samples were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation in the P/P0= 0.05–0.30 range, using a value of 0.163 cm2 for the N2 area in the equation. The cumulative pore volume and the pore size distribution were evaluated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Structural properties of the catalyst were examined using synchrotron-based X-ray Diffraction (XRD). XRD data were collected at NCD-SWEET beamline (ALBA synchrotron, Spain) in transmission mode. The X-ray beam produced by an undulator was monochromatized using a Si(111) channel cut monochromator at 12.4 keV (λ = 0.9998 Å). The X-ray beam was collimated with an array of Be lenses, obtaining a beam size at the sample position of 150 × 50 µm2 [H × V]. The detector to sample distance, tilts, and reciprocal q-space were calibrated using Cr2O3 as standard, being the detector at 233.73 mm from the sample position. For quantitative comparison, the diffractograms were normalized to the intensity of the (–111) peak of monoclinic zirconia. The relative volume fraction of tetragonal and monoclinic zirconia phases in each sample was determined using the peak intensity formula reported below [26], where IT(101), IT(110) and IM(-111) correspond to the area of the peaks (101), (110) and (-111) of t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2, respectively. % t - Zr O 2 = I T ( 101 ) + I T ( 110 ) I T ( 101 ) + I T ( 110 ) + I M ( - 111 ) 2.4.2 Catalysts reducibility A Micromeritics Autochem III instrument, equipped with a CryoCooler device allowing to perform the measurements starting from −70°C, was used for H2-TPR measurements. The water formed during the reduction process was trapped inside a molecular sieve getter located between the sample holder and the detector. In a typical experiment 200 mg of sample is introduced in the sample holder and exposed to Ar flow. Then, the sample is cooled down to −70°C under Ar flow (50 cm3 min−1). Successively, the flow is switched to 5 % H2 in Ar (50 cm3 min−1) until a constant baseline is established. At that point, the temperature ramp is started at a rate of 5°C min−1 up to 700°C. The effluent gas stream was analysed by means of a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4.3 Surface properties The surface chemical composition of the materials was analysed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), using a PHOIBOS 150 MCD instrument with an X-ray source equipped with Mg and Al anodes, a monochromatic Al and Ag source and a multichannel detector. Resulting data were processed using XPS CASA software. IR spectroscopy using CO as a probe was applied both at room temperature and at ca. 100 K (liquid nitrogen temperature). In both cases measurements were performed on a Bruker Vertex 77 spectrophotometer, equipped with an MCT detector. The samples were pressed into self-supporting pellets (mass-to-area ratio around 0.1 mg/mm2) and placed inside a home-made quartz cell equipped with KBr windows, allowing thermal treatments under vacuum and/or in presence of reactive atmosphere, and further measurements either at room temperature or at liquid N2 temperature in the presence of the probe. Before the measurements, the samples were activated directly in the cell, following the same protocol: 1) thermal treatment under degassing (5 × 10−5 mbar) up to 120 ºC (heating rate of 5 ºC/min), followed by 30 min at the same temperature; 2) a reduction step in H2 (∼100 mbar) at 120 ºC for three cycles, separated by rapid degassing; 3) a final degassing step at 120 ºC for 2 h under dynamic vacuum; 4) cooling down to room temperature. For each measurement, the IR spectrum of the activated catalyst was collected at room temperature. Subsequently, CO (∼50mbar) was introduced in the cell and another IR spectrum was recorded. At this point, for room temperature experiments, the CO pressure was decreased stepwise through controlled expansions and an IR spectrum was collected at each step, until no modifications were detected in the spectra. For low temperature experiment, instead, the sample was cooled down to about liquid nitrogen temperature in the presence of CO, until reaching the maximum CO coverage. After collecting an IR spectrum in these conditions, the CO pressure was decreased stepwise at liquid nitrogen temperature, collecting an IR spectrum at each step up to complete degassing. For quantitative purposes, the IR spectra are reported after subtracting that collected before CO dosage, and after normalization to the mass-to-area ratio of the pellet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performances The cascade conversion of furfural (FF) into alkyl levulinates is a complex reaction pathway that has been extensively investigated in the literature. Table 1 presents selected examples of catalysts - many of them based on noble metals - designed for this transformation, which demands the combination of redox and acidic functionalities within a single catalytic system. Despite these efforts, the reported yields of alkyl levulinates remain modest, highlighting the need for advanced catalyst architectures capable of efficiently integrating both types of active sites to achieve high selectivity and conversion. The catalytic activity of the Pd-based catalysts developed in this work was evaluated in the one-pot cascade transformation of FF into isopropyl levulinate (IPLE), using isopropanol as both solvent and hydrogen donor, under microwave irradiation. As anticipated in the introduction and in this section, this is a multiple-step and challenging reaction with an intricate mechanism, requiring hydrogenation of FF to FA and the successive alcoholysis of FA to the alkyl levulinate. The hydrogenation step requires the use of Pd, while alcoholysis is promoted mainly by Brønsted acid sites: hence, a bifunctional catalyst is essential. Fig. 2a shows the catalytic performance of the Pd-based catalysts, in terms of conversion and selectivity. In the absence of catalyst (blank), no significant activity is detected, except for the formation of approximately 5 % humins, which are FF polymerization byproducts favoured at high reaction temperature. In the presence of ZrO2/C the conversion reaches approximately 60 % and further increases up to 97 % when Pd is added (S0 catalyst). In the latter case, more than 95 % selectivity is directed toward the formation of FA, highlighting the ability of Pd to promote hydrogenation reactions, consistent with previous studies conducted by our group [25]. The subsequent steps to transform FA into IPLEV require the participation of Brønsted acid sites, which motivated the incorporation of SO4 groups into the catalysts. Indeed, the presence of SO4 facilitates the formation of IPLEV, with a selectivity as high as 30 % for S1–10. However, incorporation of SO4 groups leads to two detrimental effects: on one side, a sharp decrease in conversion (from 97 % to less than 30 %), and on the other the production of substantial amounts of humins, which are common FF polymerization products in the presence of Brønsted acidity. Catalyst S3–5 makes exception, because both activity and selectivity remain similar to S0, suggesting that most of the SO4 species have been removed thanks to the hydrogenation step during the synthesis. The less performant catalyst is S4–5, which has not only a poor activity, but also a scarce selectivity, enhancing only the isopropyl furfuryl ether (IPFE) intermediate. It is worth noting that, although catalysts S1–5 and S1–10 achieve the highest IPLEV yields among the series, the maximum selectivity remains around 30 %, in line with previously reported systems (Table 1). This highlights the persistent challenge in designing bifunctional catalysts capable of efficiently driving this cascade transformation, where redox and acid functionalities must operate in concert without interfering with each other. Given the promising initial activity of S1–5 and S1–10, reusability tests were performed. Due to operational limitations of the microwave reactor – unsuitable for continuous operation beyond 1 h due to potential damage to the magnetron – the reactions were carried out in sequential batches. After each run, the catalysts were recovered by filtration, washed with isopropanol and acetone, and dried in an oven at 80 ºC for 12 h before reuse in the same reaction. Surprisingly, no catalytic activity toward IPLEV was observed. This finding points to two possible deactivation mechanisms: i) Pd leaching from the catalyst structure, or ii) catalyst deactivation due to poisoning occurring under the reaction conditions, which prevents its reactivation. To understand the reasons of the scarce activity of SO4-containing catalysts, reactions were repeated using FA as substrate instead of FF (Fig. 2b). The conversion of FA follows a trend opposite to the conversion of FF: catalysts without SO4 (ZrO2/C and S0) are scarcely active, while for those containing SO4 the conversion increases from less than 30 % to over 99 % with a selectivity toward IPLEV that correlates with the nominal SO4 loading. This confirms the role of Brønsted acidity generated by SO4 in the conversion of FA, but also suggests that the Pd phase necessary to hydrogenate FF to FA is poisoned by SO4, preventing subsequent steps and promoting humins formation. The S3–5 catalyst makes again exception displaying activity and selectivity very similar to S0, suggesting once more that the SO4 species were lost during the synthesis step. Overall, these results demonstrate that while Pd and SO4 functionalities are individually effective – Pd for the hydrogenation of FF and ZrO2-SO4 for the alcoholysis of FA – their coexistence in a single catalyst can lead to detrimental interactions. In particular, the promotor of Brønsted acidity may poison or block Pd active sites, undermining the cascade process. This explains the moderate maximum yields observed, even for the best-performing bifunctional catalysts, and emphasizes that the key challenge is not simply incorporating both functionalities, but ensuring their compatibility and stability under reaction conditions. 3 3.2 Catalyst characterization All the synthetized Pd-based catalysts were subjected to a systematic investigation aimed at understanding the reasons why the SO4-doped catalysts were scarcely active in the conversion of FF despite presenting a decent selectivity towards IPLEV. The characterization data are presented in the following order. Initially, the textural and structural properties of the catalysts are discussed. The reducibility of the catalyst in H2 and synergetic effects between Pd and ZrO2 are studied by H2-TPR. Finally, the surface properties of the catalysts are analysed by IR spectroscopy using CO as molecular probe, focusing on both the acidity and the accessibility of the Pd sites. 3.2.1 Texture and structure Fig. 3a shows the N2 adsorption isotherms of the ZrO2/C composite and of samples S0 and S1-X (i.e. catalysts with increasing sulphate loadings), while Fig. 3b compares the N2 adsorption isotherms of catalysts obtained through different synthesis methods, keeping constant the nominal sulphate composition. All isotherms can be categorized as type IV(a) according to IUPAC classification, with a hysteresis loop indicative of mesoporosity. However, it is evident that ZrO2/C and S0 catalyst, which were not subjected to any calcination step during the synthesis, adsorb more N2 compared to S1-X samples, where instead the carbon phase was removed during calcination. The presence of the carbon phase in S0 and the absence of it in S1–5 is clear also by looking to HR-TEM images (Figure S1). Interestingly, changing the sulphate concentration does not significantly affect the textural properties of the obtained materials, whereas thermal treatments exert a notable influence. This is confirmed by comparing the results collected on catalysts obtained through different synthesis methods (Fig. 3b). The specific surface area (SSA) calculated with the BET model approaches 300 m2/g for ZrO2/C and S0 sample (Table 1), with approximately half of the total pore volume comprising mesopores, and the other half consisting of macropores. Instead, the SSA drops to less than 50 m2/g for the S1-X, S2–5 and S4–5 samples, while the S3–5 catalyst, which did not undergo any thermal treatment in air, retains a high SSA (∼300 m2/g). HR-TEM confirms the presence of the carbon phase in this case (Figure S1). The structural properties of the catalysts were investigated by X-ray Diffraction (XRD). The XRD patterns are reported in Fig. 4 in the q = 10–55 nm−1 range, comprising the (101) and (110) peaks characteristic of the ZrO2 tetragonal phase at ca. 21.3 nm−1 and 24.8 nm−1 respectively, and the (-111) peak of monoclinic ZrO2 at ca. 19.9 nm−1. All the samples contain a mixture of tetragonal (t-ZrO2) and monoclinic (m-ZrO2) phases at a different ratio (2). Notably, even though the starting ZrO2/C composite contains prevalently t-ZrO2, the addition of Pd followed by thermal treatments under different atmosphere promotes its transformation into m-ZrO2. The amount of tetragonal phase decreases from 64 % to 18 % in catalyst S0 and remains around 20–30 % in the S1-X series regardless of sulphate concentration and also across different synthesis. The only exception is sample S4–5, which contains 38 % of t-ZrO2. This is due to its specific synthesis conditions, where reduction of the Pd phase occurs only in the final step and at a lower temperature (100°C). These observations are in agreement with prior research [26,29], which indicates that thermal treatments in air above 500 ºC induce the t-ZrO2 → m-ZrO2 transition, while in H2 this occurs already below 160°C. The XRD patterns reveal also the presence of metallic Pd nanoparticles (NPs), characterized by a peak at 29.9 nm−1, corresponding to the Pd(111) reflection [25], observed only in samples S0 and S3–5. In the latter, the Pd(111) peak is weaker and broader compared to S0, which suggests that the Pd nanoparticles are less crystalline and/or smaller in size. Interestingly, the Pd(111) peak is absent in all catalysts of the S1-X series, regardless of the sulphate concentration (Fig. 4b), neither in samples S2–5 and S4–5 (Fig. 4c). This cannot be solely a consequence of the thermal treatments after SO4 functionalization. As a matter of fact, in sample S0–5, where sulphate groups are incorporated via mechanochemistry prior to any heat treatment, the Pd(111) peak is already missing, suggesting that the Pd phase undergoes transformation during the mechanochemical addition of SO4 species. The "absence" of the Pd(111) reflection is therefore likely related to the oxidation of metallic Pd to Pd oxide (as discussed in the next section), which is often reported as amorphous in analogous catalysts. [30] In support of this, STEM images coupled with EDX mapping reveal agglomerates of Pd phase of size up to 100 nm in sample S1–5 (Figure S1), despite the lack of a metallic Pd signature in the XRD patterns. Interestingly, the catalysts exhibiting the Pd(111) reflection are also those showing significant catalytic activity in the first step of FF hydrogenation to FA. 3.2.2 Reducibility of the Pd and S phases H2-TPR measurements were conducted to examine the oxidation state of the Pd phase across all synthesized catalysts and to quantify the reducible S-phase. The measurements were performed starting from −70 °C, to avoid partial reduction of the Pd2+ phase during the equilibration step in H2. The complete H2-TPR profiles are presented in Figure S2, while Fig. 5 shows a magnification of the two most relevant regions: i) the peaks observed in the 30 – 70°C interval are due to the Pd2+→Pd0 reduction; ii) the peaks above 150°C, instead, are ascribed to the reduction of sulphates. The integrated area below the positive peaks gives the overall hydrogen consumption in the reduction processes and allows to quantify the Pd2+ fraction present in each sample, as well as the actual amount of sulphate species. A summary of the most relevant results is reported in Table 3. The S0 catalyst (grey in Fig. 5a) exhibits a flat TPR curve, indicating the almost complete absence of reducible species. This is expected, since the Pd phase was reduced at 400°C and no sulphates were added during the synthesis. Only upon magnification (inset in Fig. 5a) three weak peaks are observed at about 30 °C (sharp), 200 °C (broad) and 500 °C (broad). The former, corresponding to a H2/Pd2+ molar ratio of 0.25, is ascribed to the reduction of a passivation PdO layer at the surface of metallic Pd NPs [30]. The other two peaks, instead, are ascribed to the Pd-mediated reduction of surface and bulk ZrO2, respectively [31]. In contrast, the H2-TPR profile of S0–5 (brown in Fig. 5a), obtained from S0 upon addition of (NH4)2SO4 via mechanochemistry but without any subsequent heat treatment, shows a very sharp and intense Pd2+→Pd0 reduction peak centred at 25 °C (with a tail at lower temperature), corresponding to a H2/Pd2+ molar ratio equal to 4:1. This clearly indicates that during the mechanochemical addition of ammonium sulphate the Pd phase gets oxidized. However, the huge H2 consumption suggests the formation of the PdSO4 salt rather than PdO, which requires 4 equivalents of H2 to be reduced to PdS, according to equation: PdS O 4 + 4 H 2 → PdS + 4 H 2 O . This indicates that a fraction of the added sulphates actually reacts with the Pd phase during mechanochemistry, rather than with the ZrO2/C support. Subsequently, PdS is proposed to undergo further reduction according to equation PdS + H 2 → Pd + H 2 S , which is responsible for the peak centred at about 160 ºC [32,33]. This means that a reduction treatment above 160 °C is sufficient to restore metallic Pd. Finally, the broad peak centred around 330°C could be attributed to the Pd-catalysed reduction of [SO4]2-, which formally requires 2 equivalents of H2 per [SO4]2- groups, if all of them are reduced following the reaction SO 4 2 − + 2 H 2 → SO 2 + 2 H 2 O [34]. However, the integrated area below this peak accounts only for approximately half of the nominal SO 4 2 − added via mechanochemistry. A possibility to explain this result is that, during the mechanochemical process, a fraction of the sulphates is reduced to sulphites, which are expected to reduce in the same temperature range but with a 1:1 stoichiometry, according to reaction SO 3 2 − + H 2 → SO 2 + H 2 O . Moving to the S1-X catalysts (Fig. 5b), which were calcined in air at 500°C after addition of ammonium sulphate via mechanochemistry, they all show a H2 consumption peak around 50°C, corresponding to a H2/Pd2+ molar ratio equal to 1.2–1.4, irrespective of the sulphate loading. This suggests that calcination at 500 °C transforms almost all the PdSO4 salt into PdO, whose reduction requires only one equivalent of H2, according to the equation PdO + H 2 → Pd + H 2 O . This PdO phase is reduced at a temperature higher than that expected for reducing bulk PdO, which suggests a strong chemical interaction between some sulphur compound and PdO, already at low [SO4]2- content. [30] It has been already reported that a very small amount of dopant is sufficient to strongly affect the reducibility of PdO [35]. Upon magnification, it is evident that the Pd2+→Pd0 reduction peak is asymmetric. A plausible hypothesis that aligns with all experimental observations is the formation of a thin PdS layer on top of PdO, which may be responsible for the broad and weak H2 consumption peak in the 150 – 250 °C range, as well as for the lack of catalytic activity in these materials. The [SO4]2-→[SO2] reduction peak appears in the same position for the S1-X series of catalysts (around 330–340°C) and with a similar integrated area, despite the nominal [SO4]2- loading is different. The H2 consumption is close to that expected from the nominal [SO4]2- loading only for the S1–3 catalyst, while at higher [SO4]2- loadings it is much less than expected and levels off, reaching a plateau corresponding to about 0.3 mmol/g of [SO4]2-. This indicates that a fraction of the sulphates is lost during the calcination at 500°C and that only a limited amount is stabilized at the ZrO2 support, largely dictated by its low surface area (∼30 m2/g). Finally, Fig. 5c compares the H2-TPR profile of S1–5 with those of catalysts having the same nominal sulphate loading but subjected to different thermal treatments. The profile of S3–5, which was subjected to H2 reduction at 500°C, is very similar to that of S0. In the region of Pd2+→Pd0 reduction, no significant reduction peaks are observed. In the [SO4]2-→[SO2] reduction region no peaks are observed, providing evidence that sulphates were removed during the H2 treatment at 500°C. This is in agreement with the H2-TPR of S0–5, which demonstrates that the SO4 groups are completely eliminated at 500 ºC under H2 atmosphere. Also S2–5 and S4–5 catalysts do not show Pd2+→Pd0 reduction peaks, which means that the Pd phase is completely reduced, but only a negative peak, indicative of the decomposition of bulk Pd hydrides [36,37]. This peak is observable only when the Pd NPs are big and enough and/or sufficiently ordered. As for the [SO4]2-→[SO2] reduction region is concerned, S2–5 shows a peak almost identical to S1–5, as expected. In fact, S2–5 differs from S1–5 only for a final H2 treatment at 100 °C, which does not affect the [SO4]2- population. S4–5, instead, is the catalyst retaining the largest amount of sulphur. It is important to notice that, differently from all the other catalysts, S4–5 is not derived directly from S0. The H2 consumption exceeds that expected from the nominal loading in terms of mmol/g, which cloud suggest that not all the sulphur is present as [SO4]2- or other reduction pathways are possible. However, the difference in specific surface area (SSA) between S4–5 and S1–5/S2–5 must also be taken into consideration. As previously demonstrated in the S1-X catalyst series, the surface area plays a crucial role in determining the amount of sulphate species retained on the catalyst. In this case, S4–5 exhibits a significantly higher SSA (70 m2/g) compared to the other air-treated materials, S1–5 and S2–5 (∼30 m2/g). If results presented in Table 2 are normalized to the surface area - expressed as mmol H2 consumed/m2 - both S4–5 and S1–5/S2–5 show a value of 0.013 mmol/m2, indicating that the sulphate density is effectively the same in both samples even they are not directly comparable in absolute terms due to the substantial difference in their surface areas. 3.3 Surface properties 3.3.1 Surface chemical composition The surface composition of the most relevant catalysts was analysed by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). This technique was selected due to its limited information depth of approximately 10 nm, making it particularly suitable for assessing the surface elemental distribution. Moreover, XPS enables the investigation of specific interactions between the constituent elements of the catalyst, which cannot be adequately evaluated using other surface analysis methods such as elemental analysis - especially challenging in this case due to the poor solubility of elements like C and Zr - or microscopy techniques. The results are summarized in Table 4. As shown in Table 4, there are significant differences in the surface composition of the catalysts. In particular, carbon is only preserved in the samples that were not thermally treated in air (S0 and S3–5). These two catalysts also exhibit either no detectable sulphur or only trace amounts, in agreement with the H₂-TPR results and consistent with their preserved reductive activity, as no sulphur-related interaction or poisoning with Pd occurs. Interestingly, the Pd content in S3–5 is lower than in S0, which may be attributed to a reduction in particle size and increased dispersion, as suggested by XRD and HR-TEM analyses discussed earlier. This could result in part of the Pd becoming embedded within the support, making it less accessible to surface-sensitive techniques such as XPS. In contrast, the catalysts treated in air show a substantially lower carbon content, further confirming the compositional changes induced by oxidative conditions. The sulphur content provides the most compelling insight. Interestingly, the sample with the highest sulphur content also shows the lowest apparent Pd concentration. This observation supports the formation of a surface PdS layer, whose presence correlates with sulphate loading, and may result in partial coverage of Pd sites. This interpretation is further reinforced by H₂-TPR data, which show a constant Pd content across all S1 samples, confirming that the metal is still present but progressively less accessible at the surface. Additionally, the low Pd content in these samples, combined with the overlap of Pd 3d with the Zr 3p signal, complicates peak fitting and prevents a clear distinction between metallic Pd and Pd²⁺ species. A similar limitation affects the S 2p region: the dominant presence of sulphate, as confirmed by H₂-TPR, and the limited sensitivity of XPS hinder the detection of any direct Pd–S interaction. Despite multiple scans and the expected formation of a thin PdS layer (but accounting for only a fraction of the total 1 % Pd), no specific Pd–S signal could be resolved. 3.3.2 Accessibility of the Pd phase The surface properties of the Pd NPs in the Pd-based catalysts were investigated by IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed at room temperature, a widely used technique for analysing the exposed sites of supported metal nanoparticles [38–42]. To this aim, the catalysts were subjected to a H2 reduction treatment at 120 ºC (as described in the experimental section), in order to have Pd in its reduced state without affecting all the other components (see TPR data). Fig. 6 shows the IR spectra collected at the maximum CO coverage in the v(CO) range (2150–1700 cm−1) and after subtracting the spectrum collected prior CO dosage. The IR spectrum of CO adsorbed at room temperature on S0 (Fig. 6a) shows two main bands at ca. 2089 cm−1 and 1923 cm−1, corresponding to linear and multi-folded coordinated carbonyls [30,43–45]. Both bands are quite broad, which suggests a certain heterogeneity of adsorption sites, making it difficult to speak about specific (hkl) exposed facets. Upon CO desorption, the two bands gradually decrease in intensity shifting at lower frequency (Figure S3). Linear carbonyls are completely reversible, which suggests a relatively weak Pd-CO interaction, likely as a consequence of a strong Pd-ZrO2 interaction. The absence of bands above 2100 cm−1 peculiar for CO adsorbed at positively charged Pd species, demonstrates the complete reduction of the Pd phase after the thermal treatment in H2 [44,45]. The IR spectra of CO adsorbed on S1–3 to S1–20 catalyst are very different from that of S0, with only a very weak band at ∼1960 cm−1 ascribable to multi-folded coordinated CO adsorbed on Pd. This indicates that, regardless of the percentage of sulphate, the metal surface is no longer accessible, substantiating the hypothesis formulated to explain the H2-TPR and XPS results, i.e the presence of a thin layer of PdS strongly interacting with PdO, which is not removed by the H2 reduction at 120°C. When comparing the IR spectra of CO adsorbed at room temperature on catalysts synthetized with different approaches at constant sulphate loading (Fig. 6b), it can be clearly observed that Pd is accessible only in catalyst S3–5, which shows IR absorption bands almost twice more intense than S0. The accessibility of the Pd NPs is attributed to the H2 reduction treatment at 500 ºC after the addition of ammonium sulphate in the synthesis of S3–5, a procedure which reduces the [SO4]2- groups (as demonstrated by H2-TPR) avoiding Pd poisoning. The higher intensity of the ʋ(CO) bands, instead is explained in terms of smaller particles size, as suggested by XRD data. These spectroscopic data are in good agreement with the catalytic results reported in Fig. 2a, which indicate that the hydrogenation reaction occurs in SO4-free catalysts, where Pd is accessible. Given that the reused S1–5 catalyst exhibited even lower activity than the fresh sample, an additional IR experiment was conducted to assess changes in the accessibility of Pd sites after reaction. Under the reductive conditions of catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) at 200 °C, the presence of a PdS surface layer is unlikely. This is corroborated by H₂-TPR data, which show that PdS decomposes above 160 °C, suggesting that Pd should remain in its active metallic form during the reaction. In contrast, as shown in Figure S4, the CO absorption bands indicate that Pd in the used catalyst is only slightly more accessible than in the fresh sample, but accessibility remains far lower compared to sulfate-free catalysts such as S0 or S3–5. A plausible explanation for these results is the migration of sulphate species during the reaction, leading to partial blocking of Pd active sites and thus contributing to catalyst deactivation. Migration of sulphates in reaction conditions could also explain the modest yet selective formation of alkyl levulinates in catalysts where Pd appears inaccessible. In this case, the catalyst already contains a thin PdS layer before reaction begins. Under the reaction conditions (200 °C, reducing environment), PdS starts to decompose – according to H₂-TPR data –temporarily exposing metallic Pd and enabling furfural hydrogenation. However, as the reaction proceeds, migration of sulphate groups toward reactivated Pd would regenerate PdS, blocking the Pd sites again. At the same time, migration of sulphates would reduce the surface acidity of the material, hindering the alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol and limiting IPLEV production. This could explain why Pd is barely detectable by IR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO, yet still plays a transient catalytic role. 3.3.3 Surface acidity The surface acidity of the Pd-based catalysts was qualitatively evaluated by means of IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed at liquid nitrogen temperature. The choice of using CO as a probe molecule rather than more popular molecules, such as pyridine, was deliberate and motivated by its ability to discriminate Brønsted acid strength through ν(CO) shifts, rather than merely detecting their presence. While pyridine is widely used to identify Brønsted acidity, its strong basicity can lead to protonation even on weak acid sites, thus preventing discrimination between strong and moderate acid sites in sulphated zirconia systems. [46] Additionally, pyridine is known to interact strongly with metallic Pd surface [47] possibly leading to undesired reactivity and surface by-products, which may complicate its use as a neutral probe in Pd containing materials. In contrast, CO interacts more subtly with surface hydroxyls, and its IR response provides a more sensitive and selective measure of Brønsted acid strength and metal site accessibility under cryogenic conditions. Fig. 7 shows, for each catalyst, the IR spectra of CO adsorbed at liquid nitrogen temperature as a function of coverage, in both ʋ(CO) (main graphs) and ʋ(OH) (insets) regions. In the ʋ(CO) region, the spectra can be divided in two main parts. 1) The IR absorption bands below 2100 cm−1 are related to CO adsorbed on Pd, as discussed in the previous section. The intensity of these bands depends on the accessibility of the Pd NPs, and they are completely irreversible at this temperature. They will not be discussed in this section. 2) The bands above 2000 cm−1, instead, are associated to CO adsorbed at the Brønsted acid sites. Their position is a sensitive indicator of the acid strength: the larger the shift with respect to the ʋ(CO) of gaseous CO (2143 cm−1), the stronger the Brønsted acidity. The ʋ(CO) region is mirrored by the behaviour of the ʋ(OH) bands. In fact, CO adsorption causes a perturbation of the OH bands: stronger the interaction, larger the shift of the ʋ(OH) bands [48]. Starting the discussion from S0, at the maximum CO coverage a symmetric ʋ(CO) band is observed at 2151 cm−1; correspondingly, in the ʋ(OH) region, the band at ∼3695 cm−1 downward shifts to 3600 cm−1. This behaviour indicates that CO is primarily adsorbed on surface hydroxyl groups with no Brønsted acidity. The S3–5 catalyst displays very similar spectra, demonstrating once more that the H2 treatment at 500°C leads to the decomposition of sulphates. In contrast, the spectra of CO adsorbed on catalysts containing sulphate groups exhibit a ʋ(CO) band at 2161 cm−1, while in the ʋ(OH) region a band ∼3665 cm−1 downwards shift to 3550 cm−1. This indicates that the presence of sulphate groups induces a moderate Brønsted acidity. S1–5 and S1–20 catalysts exhibit the strongest Brønsted acid sites, in larger amount in S1–20 (band more intense), followed by S2–5 and finally S4–5 catalysts. In addition, at lower CO coverages, a weak band appears in the 2175–2165 cm−1 region, which is due to CO adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, typically associated with under-coordinated Zr4+ sites. The observed ν(CO) band positions (Δν ≈ +14 to +18 cm−1 relative to the gas-phase CO (2143 cm−1) are consistent with previous data reported for Brønsted acid sites on sulphated zirconia [49] but significantly lower than those typically observed for strong Brønsted sites in protonic zeolites. [50] Nonetheless, in both material classes, differences of just a few wavenumbers in the ν(CO) have been shown to reflect meaningful variations in Brønsted acid strength. These findings are consistent with the catalytic results related to the alcoholysis step (Fig. 2b). The selectivity towards IPLEV correlates with the strength and the abundance of the Brønsted acid sites. S0 and S3–5 catalysts show the lowest Δʋ(CO) (i.e. no Brønsted acidity) and they do not produce IPLEV at all. In contrast, the S1–20 catalyst shows the highest ʋ(CO) shift (i.e. the strongest Brønsted acidity) and the most intense band (i.e. more abundant) and, consequently, the best catalytic performance. Moreover, although S4–5 has the highest SO₄²⁻ content, as demonstrated by H₂-TPR, the strength of these acid sites is lower than in S1–5 and S2–2 as the ν(CO) band positions show. This explain absence of IPLEV in the catalytic test for S4–5 with respect to S1–5 and S2–5 (Fig. 2a). 3.4 Tuning the reduction conditions is not enough to ensure excellent catalysts activity According to the results discussed above, the poor performances of the Pd-based catalysts in the one-pot transformation of furfural into isopropyl levulinate can be explained in terms of poisoning of the Pd phase by a PdS layer, which is formed during the calcination step and can be removed only upon reduction in gaseous H2 at temperatures above 160 °C. Hence, under CTH reaction conditions, the Pd phase is still not accessible, preventing the first step of the reaction to occur due to a cyclic mechanism. On the other hand, the sulphate groups necessary for the second step of the reaction begin to decompose under molecular H2 above 300 °C. This suggests that the reduction conditions must be carefully selected within the 160–300 °C range to simultaneously preserve Brønsted acidity and avoid Pd deactivation. Following these conclusions and to confirm the cyclic mechanism, the S0–5 material was reduced under hydrogen at 200 °C to prevent the formation of a PdS layer, while maintaining the sulphate groups intact. The obtained catalyst was then tested in the conversion of furfural to isopropyl levulinate under the same conditions discussed above. Unfortunately, it showed catalytic performances similar to S1–5 and S2–5 catalysts, suggesting the persistence of Pd poisoning. This could confirm that, under CTH reaction conditions, i.e. in the presence of liquid isopropanol, the sulphate groups at the catalyst surface are mobile and can migrate from the support to the Pd NPs, causing their deactivation. This is corroborated by the observation of sulphur leaching at a certain extent. To confirm this, a simple test was performed: after completing the reaction, the catalyst was removed and an additional amount of furfuryl alcohol was added to the reaction mixture. At this point, reaction was carried out again at same conditions. In the absence of the catalyst, a slight increase in the alcoholysis products was still observed - which did not happen in blank catalyst test (Fig. 2) - indicating that the reaction continued to a small extent. This confirms that some sulphate groups had leached into the reaction medium and remained active. Future developments should focus on maintaining the use of mechanochemistry for Pd incorporation – as it leads to highly dispersed Pd NPs when the material is treated under inert atmosphere – at the same time preventing the migration and detachment of sulphate groups from the catalyst surface. Anchoring the sulphate groups before the insertion of Pd might be a possible strategy to prevent their migration. For example, the use of an organic linker bearing sulfonic acid functionalities, such as 2-sulfoisophthalic acid, would allow for covalent incorporation of sulphates into the framework of the MOF. Since the subsequent transformation to ZrO₂ is performed under inert conditions, these functional groups might remain intact. This methodology would lead to a higher and more homogeneous acid site density on the catalyst surface, which could be tuned by adjusting the molar ratio of functionalized linkers – using, for instance, a combination of 2-aminoterephthalic acid with 2-sulfoisophthalic acid. 4 Conclusions This study offers a mechanistic perspective on the structural and functional limitations of Pd-based bifunctional catalysts derived from NH₂-UiO-66(Zr) for the one-pot conversion of furfural into isopropyl levulinate. Rather than showcasing a superior catalytic formulation, we aimed to recognize the complex interactions between the metallic (Pd) and acidic (SO4 2-) functions within ZrO₂–carbon composites, and how synthesis conditions - particularly the sequence of the synthetic steps, temperature and reactive atmosphere - influence these interactions. Our results reveal that the mechanochemical functionalization of the Pd-ZrO2/C catalyst (S0) with ammonium sulphate (yielding S0–5) not only deposits sulphate species, but also oxidizes Pd into PdSO4. Subsequent calcination at 500°C in air (S1-X series) leads to carbon loss, decreased specific surface area, and PdSO4 decomposition into PdO, which remains poorly reducible due to strong interaction with residual sulphur, likely forming a thin PdS layer. Characterization by H2-TPR confirmed that PdS is reduced only above 160 °C, indicating that under CTH conditions, with isopropanol as H-donor, PdO may be partially reduced to Pd NPs, but these remain largely inaccessible due to sulphur poisoning cyclic mechanism. This sulphur-induced deactivation is not a static phenomenon but a dynamic, tuneable mechanism governed by the material’s synthetic history. Milder reduction post-treatments, such as H2 at 100 °C (S2–5) fail to restore Pd accessibility, while harsher H2 treatment at 500°C (S3–5) completely removes sulphur species, restoring accessibility, but also eliminating the SO4 2- groups essential for Brønsted acidity. Even altering the synthesis sequence, as in S4–5, yields catalysts structurally similar to S2–5, with metallic Pd still poisoned by PdS. This interdependence reveals a central challenge in multifunctional catalyst design: preserving one functionality often compromises the other. Our multi-technique investigation mapped the evolution of Pd speciation (PdSO4 → PdO → PdS→ Pd→ PdS) and linked it to performance under CTH reaction conditions. Although the studied catalysts do not surpass current benchmarks in catalytic activity, they offer critical insight into failure modes caused by sulphur-related poisoning and active site masking. Going forward, improved synthesis protocols must be coupled with reaction condition engineering to prevent uncontrolled sulphate migration and Pd masking. Our findings highlight the necessity of balancing functional domains in catalyst architectures and point toward a more nuanced understanding of how deactivation evolves under realistic reaction environments. coredata.dc:description: Understanding why multifunctional catalysts fail is critical to advancing biomass valorisation strategies. In this study, we systematically investigate the dynamic deactivation mechanisms that limit the one-pot cascade conversion of furfural (FF) to alkyl levulinates via sequential hydrogenation and alcoholysis. To this end, we designed a series of bifunctional Pd/SO4 2 --ZrO2–carbon composites derived from NH2-UiO-66(Zr) through pyrolysis, followed by mechanochemical functionalization. Rather than focusing on catalytic performance, our goal was to elucidate how variations in synthetic protocol – specifically the sequence of pyrolysis, sulphation, calcination atmosphere, and reduction steps – influence structural evolution, Pd–sulphur interactions, and active site accessibility. Through a broad multi-technique characterization campaign, we reveal that Pd deactivation by sulphur is a gradual and reversible process, closely related to the catalyst’s thermal history. While high-temperature H₂ treatments can restore Pd accessibility, they also strip Brønsted acidity by removing surface SO42— groups, revealing a compromise between hydrogenation and alcoholysis functions. These findings highlight the complexity of designing truly cooperative multifunctional catalysts and the importance of integrated synthetic–reactive strategies that move beyond performance optimization alone.

coredata.dc:title: Deciphering catalyst failure: Sulphur–palladium interplay in the one-pot conversion of furfural to isopropyl levulinate
